Content: Cameraman: How are we going to continue making this documentary without spoiling anything?
Schafer: I don't know.
People know now if they've, hopefully they're not watching this episode before they finish Act One.
You really shouldn't watch this episode.
Should we you shoot that now?
Hi. I'm Tim Schafer.
Please don't watch this episode until you finish Act One of Broken Age.
Offscreen Voice: Backers that play it, or are you more nervous about the money,
like how much it's going to sell?
Schafer: No. I mean, I feel like it's tense about the money because we want it to do well, because I have big plans for Act Two.
And if we don't do well, Justin will be like, look, look, we can't, we got to, you know.
Because basically, just spending our own money from here on out.
And probably like a few months back.
So if no one buys the game tomorrow, maybe Act Two will be a much smaller than Act One.
I hope one person buys it.
If no one buys it, it's going to be really awkward.
But I guess that's a good clear, I can say that to the backers.
Look, nobody bought it, except for you guys.
I'm sorry.
But it serves me right for investing our own money in a game.
I should have just played with their money.
[Music] Schafer: We are launching Red's tomorrow.
Crazy times.
All of our backers.
Thank you to our team for working so hard.
We are going to the backers tomorrow and the rest of the general population, future backers, if you will on the 28th.
Rice: The game is up.
Preorders are up.
Schafer: Whoohoo! Rice: Yeah.
Schafer: All right, next game.
Rice: I will send the press release.
One of the reviewers said he didn't go to bed.
Finished the game last night.
Remo: Finished it last night?
Rice: Yeah. Remo: Wow.
Rice: Yeah, I sent the codes at like...
Remo: Did he say how long it took him?
Rice: 4:00 or 5:00 p.m. Remo: Oh, right.
Rice: So I mean, I guess there's time.
But yeah, he just didn't stop.
That's kind of awesome.
Schafer: Man, this is weird.
People are playing Broken Age.
Seven people watching him and I'm one of them.
I don't want them to know this is what I do.
I've never done this before.
We've never been able to do this before and have live streams, like after Grim Fandango.
Remo: People are already posting screenshots.
Bailey: I'm still waiting.
I'm just curious who's going to be the first one to like post a review.
Remo: Yeah, right.
Rice: Tim, did you hear that? Schafer: What?
Rice: Digital Trends posted an article, "Why We're Breaking the Broken Age Embargo." And how they're going to review it.
Schafer: Well, what embargo are they breaking?
Rice: The review embargo.
They're going to put a review up.
Schafer: They're just announcing they're going to break it?
Rice: Yeah. Schafer: Why?
Rice: Because they paid for the game and they're a backer.
And they're getting it because they paid for it.
Schafer: But we, but they're not, they're in the Beta...
Rice: They haven't reviewed it yet, but Digital Trends, I know.
They emailed me about this yesterday and that's what I told them.
Remo: Technically no one signed anything so there's nothing we can actually do about it now. Rice: Yeah.
Schafer: What do you think about that? Bailey: I'm sorry?
Rice: Yeah, I don't think there's anything we can about it.
Bailey: Well, unless we have something in writing.
Remo: No, we don't. Embargoes are not really enforceable.
Bailey: Exactly. It's a professional...
Remo: I know, I know. It's a courtesy.
A professional courtesy, yeah.
Schafer: Well, maybe he didn't agree to anything but he knows he's being a shit.
Schafer: It's like people don't realize that everything's embargo.
Like every review they read has usually been embargoed, because your game's coming out and people want the press for the game
to come up on launch day or around that time people can buy it.
'Cause if it comes out before, then all that energy, people see that article, they can't go buy it.
So anyway.
You want your, you want to time your press to that day, but different reporters can come in at different times
and they're like hey, I want to, you know, just because this guy came in a week early,
does that mean his review gets to go up a week earlier?
So you say it's embargoed, so that all the press has a fair chance of getting their story, not getting scooped or whatever.
And they also have time with the build to do a thoughtful build instead of racing to like getting it out early.
But we were going out to backers and 90,000 people had the build and I think most of the regular backers were like,
OK, yeah, this is private information.
I won't spoil it for people who can't buy it yet.
And the press understood it.
But there's kind of this grey area of people between backers and press, like a, kind of like a blogger, you know, who's a backer,
who's like, hey, I paid money for this.
This guy's amazed to see consumers suggest the press should stick their heads in the sand because Double Fine asked them to nicely.
For the evening crowd, the Broken Age embargo's a bit of a joke.
Has anyone else contacted you from actual news outlet? Rice: IGN.
Schafer: Do they want to review it or just, what'd they say?
Rice: Yeah, it was just yesterday.
It's like I just want to be clear on what's expected.
He says like I feel like there's so many people that are going to be having the game.
Like if other people start running their reviews, we're going to feel like we're going to have to run ours.
That's basically what they said.
Schafer: Why don't we just let the people who are not being jerks about it break the embargo?
Rice: We can't do that.
Schafer: And that would scoop all the people who are being jerks about it.
Why, we can't do that?
Rice: I don't know how to enforce that.
Schafer: Just pick the ones that are being nice about it and just tell them they can.
Then one day later tell everyone else.
Rice: Yeah. I think that only serves to inflate the issue, because then they think the embargo is still there
and then it's being broken and then it's a mess.
So I think we have to, Schafer: It's kind of a mess, though, I think now.
Rice: Well, then, that's the case and I think we have to talk about lifting it.
And then I'm fine like, I've been saving the list of people I've emailed all the review stuff
so it would really be like a two second Kickstarter update and emailing them all, if you want to just totally lift things.
Schafer: Maybe we could just open it in a couple days, kind of.
Rice: Just sit on it for a second and see.
Schafer: Yeah. Rice: OK.
Schafer: God, that embargo's a disaster.
Schafer: And so because like one or two people were threatening to like break it, that all of a sudden made everybody else who wasn't breaking it like a chump.
And I didn't want them, you know, to feel, so we just like, look, OK.
We take back our request that no one's, go ahead.
Post all the reviews and stuff.
So a bunch of our reviews went up when people couldn't buy the game.
So that was kind, it took away a lot of our, like our press hit for the launch day, which is too bad.
But it seemed like it was, it would, we just couldn't, it was out of control.
There was just like 90,000 people, even if like 80,000 of them are totally like, yeah, it's cool.
But if like just a few took one or two breaks, then the whole thing just falls apart.
Schafer: All our backers are so cool, but the backers who are in the press feel a little differently.
They feel they have the option to not be cool.
It's an awkward situation.
Next time we wouldn't, I think actually have private forums for that reason.
Schafer: I mean, I feel in end that I just don't, I just don't want to have this fight any more about private stuff and all.
It just puts, I mean, being in this antagonist relationship with the press is just not comfortable,
'cause you need them and they're usually really good friends of ours.
I'm just getting mad at them one by one for breaking the faith of the backer agreement.
It's annoying.
Bailey: You know, one third of our, of all the articles that were written about Broken Age were about the embargo.
And then another third were about us going from early access changing it to a regular release.
And then one third were about the game. Yeah. So.
Rice: If we're saying backer Beta's the 14th and public release is the 28th, that would give the press builds like the 12th or something.
And embargo them, Bailey: This is an interesting one, because I think this is the next one that could lead to a PR blowup.
Bailey: Yeah. I was not in favor of the embargo.
Rice: But preorders are there like you said.
So people can still at least go and get the preorder.
Bailey: So the preorders are, they're less than we expected.
They are, we were hoping that they'd come in higher.
If I had to project off the preorders we received so far, that would be a kind of bleak outlook as far as how many we'd actually sell,
you know, for the lifetime of Broken Age.
But I'm basing everything off if different historicals for other games that Tim has sold and none of those have had this kind of Kickstarter story.
So this is definitely unique.
I don't think it's time for us to panic right now, but it puts a whole lot more emphasis and importance on January 28th
when it comes out for real.
'Cause I think it will do well in the long-run, but it's like how long is that run.
The other piece that I think is kind of silver-lining in all this is the reviews are coming in really good.
You know, I foresee that the game's going to have a great word-of-mouth buzz.
Most of Tim's games actually do.
And they have a, it has a very long tail.
There're games, what people call "evergreen games", they keep on selling at a certain, certain level and they just keep on,
which keeps on accumulating over the years, which is different than most games.
Most games have that huge spike, that hump, that six-weeks hump.
Tim's are different.
So that's one good thing to take into account with all the good reviews and all the social media and the good word of mouth we're having.
You know, it's like we can't get to a place where we could sell this game quick enough,
because that's where we're really going to be able to see and project, you know, what the success of the game's going to be.
Rice: So the other thing Tim was talking about is just that now that we have to move the embargo up and reviews are out now,
the idea of flipping the switch on Steam earlier.
Schafer: Releasing it a, a week earlier.
Like next Tuesday.
Schafer: Sure, whatever.
and like, you know, Schafer: Well, that's the question.
I mean, and there's, I mean there's a legitimate business reason, I think about it just because it's out there,
it's getting a lot of attention right now and there's a lot of press I'm going to do in the next week.
And it'd be nice if people, I mean can go pre-purchase it, but they can't buy it.
Rice: It'd be nice to have a story about the game being pushed forward.
Franzke: I voiced my concern about this plan.
I mean technically it does make like, like just looking at how the long the things take, just doesn't really make all that much sense.
Franzke: And you know, I explained like that.
That we can certainly do it but it will be very unadvisable, especially considering that time when that was first proposed.
We still had big problems with crashes and people not being able to play the game at all.
So that was my main worry, that you know, we were still like trying to find the really big issues and so.
So we didn't feel like it was ready to ship it then.
But I think now, basically I don't think anything will have changed if we final release it on the planned day we had initially,
just because technically time-wise it doesn't really work out any other way, anyways.
Schafer: But it's good.
So now the official reviews, now they are rolling in.
The great thing is that they're all really great.
I mean, that Polygon one was nine out of ten, which is great.
I mean, I would give it a ten, but I'll accept a nine.
Polygon Review: Broken Age may be unfinished, but it's also delightful, beautiful, utterly charming
and you really should play it right this second.
Stapley: No, it's cool.
It's awesome that it sounded like, that we all made an awesome thing now.
Like this is the cool part, you know.
Like we made this awesome thing and now it's out in the world for everybody to look at.
Rice: Yeah, I guess. Stapley: OK. How many reviews are there now.
Crook: But it feels good.
And people seem to be really responding to the game.
The reviews have been really good.
And even comments about animation, which you don't get that often.
It seems like in games a lot of times, maybe you will a couple of times.
But there's been several other reviews that have mentioned the animation, that they really, that they really liked it.
And that's, that's rewarding.
Oh, yeah. Yeah.
I saw a nine today; that's nice.
But you know, I actually, I feel kind of bad I don't really, I try not to read a lot of the reviews
because the bad ones do kind of make me, put me down.
You know, they kind of, you know, when you're kind of on this high that you've released it
and then suddenly, even though if there's like six good reviews and one bad one, that bad one kind of affects me.
So I try not to read a lot of the comments until a little bit later on.
Heatseeker Review: Broken Age gets by on the strength of its storytelling.
The puzzles aren't particularly complex or compelling with the exception of a certain vomiting tree.
And serve as a reason to explore the environments.
I can't say I recommend this to people who don't already have a fondness for this genre.
Compared to modern entries in the genre like those from Telltale Games, it may seem a little simple or even boring.
Schafer: This is actually just new posts, for new posts today.
Oh God. The guy wants a refund.
It's like, ah. This is a jerk.
I'm just going to say it.
This is a jerk.
Thanks for backing, jerk.
Franzke: You know, it's unrealistic to expect that people will be able to please everybody, obviously.
Unfortunately very often the people who are the most dissatisfied are also the loudest ones, you know, which can be difficult,
especially if you're pouring a lot of effort and a lot of work and a lot of your like, like "soul's" the wrong word,
but like a lot of your personal kind of effort into the game.
Like to see somebody come in and like just completely smash it.
I did the mistake and I should know better after so many years in games.
I think I went in Kotaku where they had an article about the "Retro Mode".
And like one of the comments, and you should never do that if you work in games.
Never read the comments.
Actually, generally don't read any internet comments.
I scroll down and somebody was like, this just look shit.
Like this is, you know, here, here's a comparison to a hand painted, hand painted sprites, versus down-res
It's like, yes, obviously.
And then backers immediately jumped in "Well they just put it in as a little add on" Still the person was not satisfied with that at all.
And then he's like, well, if you were a backer you would see that, you know, they just put in during the weekend as a little side project.
I'm not a backer but this is shit.
I'm not going to buy this.
It gets, [throws hands up, exasperated].
Having said all that, overall I think people are very happy.
I've got a lot of Tweets from people who are super happy with the project.
On the forums people are very happy, you know.
We saw someplace where some people like really, really enjoying the game.
And like, you know, it's good to see super-positive reactions of somebody just like laughing about all the jokes in the game.
And just generally like finding the game very beautiful and stuff like that.
So it's good.
Web Streamer: Fuck yeah!
Web Streamer: I don't know! Which one! What do I pick!
Oohh.
Shay: This must be where Marek sleeps.
Web Streamer: So he keeps the costume on while he sleeps.
That's funny.
Man, this is a genius game, genius story.
Schafer: I'm super happy that no one seems to have guessed the big spoiler at the end of it.
I really thought that was going to get out.
And actually long ago on the forums, one guy guessed it.
And no one followed up on it.
Like no one, he just said his little thing, hey, what if this is the case?
And no one answered him.
I was like, oh man.
I feel, oh God.
You know, I hate that guy for guessing it, but I'm really, it's worth something.
We should send him some chocolate.
But everyone else has just had the exact like experience that I was hoping for, which is that they were really like, oh my God!
I didn't see that coming, that's crazy.
Web Streamer: It's Shay!
Shay was controlling Mog Chothra.
Web Streamer: Uhhh, Shay?
Web Streamer: What the heck?
What the heck?
That's Shay!
Schafer: But they all seemed to really be enjoying the ending.
And so I'm really happy with that.
And I'm really happy with people's response to like the story, the characters.
And a lot of people, I think, will actually appreciate the difficulty level in the game once we get out of the most hardcore part of the audience.
I think they'll like that, that it flows more as opposed to hitting a series of really, really hard stops, for most people.
Schafer: I mean, you can tell they already anticipated that.
After play-testing the first part, I was like, I think this is a little easy, but I think rather than just throwing a monkey wrench, Monkey Island joke,
in there, I'm really focusing on Act Two and making Act Two a little more, instead of things being one step, having them be a little more complex.
So I'm way ahead of them, way ahead of them on that.
Petty: You know, I think, yeah, it's interesting.
Like the, I don't, I don't think I read anything that I felt was unfair and it all seemed pretty balanced.
There were, I think, you know, there's some comments about length, maybe a couple of them.
And that's kind of difficult, because you know, I mean, this was the same on Stacking.
You know, you can, you can burn through an adventure game and, and that can really shorten your play experience.
But I don't know if that's the best way to evaluate that particular game.
You know, it's not a game that has a mechanic that just like is endlessly playable.
So it's a little, I don't know, you know, it's just, it's just something that happens with adventure games that, I've seen that come up.
I don't necessarily disagree with it, but I guess I don't know what to say about it, you know.
But I think, you know, in some other stuff is stuff that we discussed early on that I've seen like, you know, the lack of a verb coin or a verb page.
And I think that's just a choice Tim, and I think the correct choice Tim made early on, you know.
I don't think there's probably people played Machinarium that also was like, this would be better if I could have a look and examine and verb link.
But I don't really feel like the experience needed it in any way and I don't really feel like Broken Age needs it in anyway.
And I don't really feel like that's where we puzzle depth, mechanical depth anyways.
So you know, I mean, I wouldn't oppose it if someone really, really, like we had started the game and we really, really wanted to take that approach.
But I just like the idea of you know, I think Tim's initial vision for the game would be like, well, what if adventure games just kept going?
And we just were keeping it working.
We wouldn't keep making the exact same thing.
We'd try and mess with the formula and advance things and I think that's what we tried to do with visuals.
We didn't want to make retro visuals, right.
We wanted to make visuals that were 2D and charming, but also took advantage of modern methodologies and technologies and resolutions.
And I think the approach to the game play is consistent with that.
And this is a choice.
You know, and some people will want that exact Monkey Island moment and some people are like, thank God, the puzzles aren't that confusing, you know.
It's hard, it's hard to get the right.
Petty: So what I would like to do is next week, since Bagel's out for two weeks and I wanted him to come out at this time so we could kick off Act Two.
So I would like to kind of, at the very least, we'll see who has time.
At the very least Bagel and Levi and myself to start concept jamming next week on early Act Two stuff.
And Tim hasn't delivered the final design or dialogue yet, but I already know some of high level stuff
and then hopefully we can get him to kind of, I can kind of like mention all that and he can kind of correct me
where he's changed things and just get us going.
So there's definitely a new, at least one new area that has no presence at all in the current act that we have to design.
And we had some very early stuff on it from before, but we haven't thought about it in 18 months.
So we'll probably start there.
Stapley: So are these the only new, this is like pretty much all we have to worry, really worry about, right?
I mean, those only new things?
Petty: Well, this is the new stuff we know about for sure.
So I thought we'd start there. OK.
So the thing that Tim, like he's going to be here after lunch, we can him some more questions
but the thing that we know for sure is that we need a monster lands area.
It's probably also a good chance for us to think about where we want to go with, you know, as we're developing him,
if we want to go anyplace different with Marek.
Here's another concept that we can think about.
Is we talked about, OK, what Alex's is.
And originally Tim kept saying, well, it's, oh, this'll be a copy of Mog Chothra to save time.
And I was saying, well, that's not really going to save us much time.
I mean, it'll save a week or so of production time, but...
Stapley: It's got to be like older version.
Petty: Right. Like it's been buried.
It's not going to look the same.
I'd love to see it like a previous generation.
Because when we were starting to draw like, I don't know, maybe, like some of these older ones or whatever,
like remember we had all those ideas like, oh, it's got diamond-shape eyes instead of hex eyes.
Ryken: Yeah, just like changes with times.
400 years, like, oh yeah, but then he came around to hexes again.
And then it went away for another 100 years.
Petty: We added two sides to our windows.
Stapley: That's awesome. That's always the best.
Like in Star Wars, you're like, well, that's R2D2, but it's a fucking red R2D2 and it's like different.
Awesome. I always love that.
Petty: Well plus it would be cool, too, like this one doesn't have, it's been buried for however long
so it doesn't have to look as purely organic, you know.
Like we're not, we're no longer trying to make people believe it's just a monster.
So being able to see some combination of the mechanical and the monster...
Ryken: Yeah, like the outer hull is just like ripped away and most of the parts.
Stapley: But it'll still be the same like rig kind of set up, right?
Petty: I mean, it could be whatever we want.
Bog Chothra.
Stapley: Bog Chothra?
Bog, I like that one.
I like Bog.
Ryken: Just Bob.
Stapley: Bob Chothra? Awesome.
That would be fucking sweet.
Stapley: All right. Should we call Scott and get pumped?
Stapley: Yeah! Look, whoo!
Hey, bro, get us pumped up!
Get us pumped up!
We're all like, boo, drawing is stupid.
He still in bed?
Campbell: Chilling on the couch.
Stapley: Oh, man.
Campbell: I was just, I was just watching Triplets of Belleville.
Stapley: Oh, sweet, dude.
Campbell: What are you guys, what are you guys doing?
Stapley: We're doing an art jam, dude.
We're doing an art jam and nobody's pumped up and like, like nobody fucking is as psyched as you.
You got to get us psyched.
You know, when you and Peter are here, you guys are like, ooh, ooh, ooh!
So come on, bro, do it, go for it.
Ryken: We need some art cheerleading.
Campbell: Get psyched, man.
What are you guys working on? Tell me about it.
Stapley: All right, check it out. Rice: What are you doing?
Stapley: Monster lands. Uh oh, look who it is.
What, tall man. Petty: Scott!
Stapley: Yeah, we're all getting pumped. OK, cool.
This is one monster, man.
Schafer: Who are you talking to?
Hi! Scott Campbell!
Hi! Everybody's at the art jam.
Stapley: I'm excited to hear about what we're going to do, because, 'cause I know that we all like, this is like,
not really trial and error but I got pretty much trial and error.
You get closer to the end, everything started working really smoothly.
So you know, it's going to be way better for sure, you know, 'cause we learned so much.
But I'm, I'm actually excited to see how we take all the things that we learned, trial and error-wise
and try to get it, you know, see what happens with the next, how organized we are, what we learned.
Schafer: OK.
Stapley: Those are the new things.
Schafer: Monster lands and the gate Stapley: And there's only the pollution inside like the kingdom.
Schafer: Don't film his armpits.
Stapley: Oh God, are they like, oh God!
Fuck. It's horrible.
Hey, bro.
Schafer: Aren't you glad you're not here right now?
It would be nice to get the main characters some different outfits, just to make the game feel... Petty: So would she put on a space suit?
Schafer: I see her with the radiation suit and I don't know necessarily if he, I can't think of, I haven't thought of a puzzle.
What?
Stapley: He could be in a cake dress.
Petty: We should do a transgender thing where he starts dressing like a girl, 'cause he gets the maiden,
leftover maiden's outfits and she dresses like a boy.
Schafer: I mean, he could put a druid cloak or he could, but he could put on a preener outfit.
remember we have those artworks, you had him masquerade as a preener for a while.
He could possibly have to do that.
I just think it would be more fun for the player to have them look really different.
Petty: He needs like a traveling cloak or something.
Piece it together. Yeah.
[Music] Franzke: Other than doing some concept artwork,
nobody has to get started working on the second act anyways, so a lot of us are still working on bug fixes for this release.
And it's, you know, it's incremental update to the backer release.
So you know, I'm really optimistic that this is all like minor fixes to be put in.
But we're pretty solid, solid release.
Peck : We are investigating an issue with the track pad on Linux for laptops with track pads.
There's a little issue there.
A little oversensitive, you might say.
Franzke: You make a change and like, oh, it works on Windows and then you go into Linux.
Aaah! Gosh, it's broken.
What the hell is going on?
Franzke: It was good to a have Beta release for sure, to kind of find a lot of issues and all the things we ran into,
we were not unprepared for, but we didn't expect.
Like a lot of Window compatibility issue than we expected, for example.
And you know, that's why I have those guys here, like we had a lot of issues with compatibility,
so we ordered a lot of graphics cards just to kind of, trying to reproduce some of the issues that users were running into.
Franzke: Oh, this is what compatibility is all about.
Finding really, really old hardware and putting in your machine and see what happens.
Franzke: You know, where here in the studio we didn't really have any problems running the game
and like our external QA partner didn't have any problem running the game,
but then as soon as we, you know, we launched it on, you know, on the day for the backers, like immediately people came back,
oh, the game is crashing or sending out a black screen and stuff like that.
That's always like, crap.
If we would not have done it like that, we would have eventually run into this issues so you know,
on the 28th we would have released the game and people would have had big problems with it and like,
while crashes are not great, but at least acceptable during a Beta,
like once the game is out there, you know, it becomes very less acceptable.
Franzke: This VGA out. Haven't seen that in a while.
I don't know if it's even still possible.
Franzke: I had, I think two crashes on Windows 98.
I mean, I was surprised that you managed to download Steam on that machine, I guess.
But yeah, unfortunately the game does not run on Windows 98 and I don't think it's part of the minimum requirement.
But yeah, that was, that was certainly very funny and surprising for sure.
Franzke: I knock on the graphics card right here.
Romero: And for right now we're in shooting crashes and blockers and people's progress is lost, saved and corrupted stuff like that.
I mean, for now it's like the forum is the bug list pretty much, 'cause there's so much coming in.
So before I was in, you know, I was looking through our bugs and now I'm looking through all these bugs.
Now they're the testers.
They're reporting the bugs to us.
We're merely the conduit through which, you know, we get the bugs to developer.
Lui: It's nice, I think, for the team to have an overview of how the overall progress is going.
So it's nice to be able to see, like look at the chart and be like, oh, we are constantly going down.
And there are spikes, like this spike over there is when Tim played through the game twice and submitted about fifteen pages of bug fixes.
Schafer: Should realize that it's gotta be done this week.
